p: Besides thymol, the main components identified in the L. thymoides essential oil were p-cymene (2.97 ± 2.79%–8.97 ± 0.64%), γ-terpinene (2.75 ± 3.55%–12.36 ± 4.64%), thymyl acetate (4.92 ± 0.10%–7.22 ± 2.30%), and E-caryophyllene (5.21 ± 0.44%–8.84 ± 1.10%). The oxygenated monoterpenes were the predominant chemical class, reaching the highest level in fresh leaves (72.95 ± 2.89%). These results were in agreement with previously published data on the composition of L. thymoides essential oils [ 30, 31], but differed from the composition described by Silva et al. (2016) [ 29], who found an essential oil with high levels of β-caryophyllene (17.22–26.27%), borneol (4.45–7.36%), camphor (3.22–8.61%), camphene (2.64–5.66%), and germacrene D (4.72–6.18%) [ 29].
